newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen B shares end lower on weak sentiment.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B shares end lower on weak sentiment.

text.p: Shenzhen's B share index closed slightly lower on Wednesday as some impatient Chinese investors trimmed their B share holdings to purchase selected A shares that are performing strongly, brokers said.
The B share index shed 0.43 points, or 0.48 percent, to close at 89.49 on turnover of HK$20.14 million, compared with HK$24.33 million on Tuesday.

Brokers said some Chinese investors with B share holdings had become increasingly impatient about being stuck in the stagnant B share market and were diverting funds into buying strong A share companies.
B share sentiment has turned weak and more Chinese investors' funds are likely to flow to the A share market in the coming sessions, one analyst said.
But overseas institutions were seen buying a handful of large-cap issues with good earnings outlooks, which limited the index's loss, he said.
Chiwan Wharf was the day's biggest loser on speculative selling, brokers said. The counter slumped HK$0.29, or 7.63 percent, to HK$3.51, with 22,000 shares traded.
China Bicycle followed suit, skidding HK$0.12, or 6.15 percent, to HK$1.83.

Dadonghai, which listed 80 million B shares in Shenzhen on Tuesday, lost HK$0.01 to HK$1.27 on the session's most active trade of 1.70 million shares. The B shares were offered recently at HK$1.22 per share.
Tellus Machinery, Tuesday's biggest loser, rallied HK$0.15, or 10.34 percent, to HK$1.60 on volume of 13,100 shares on Wednesday.
Supported by institutional demand, Guangdong Power charged ahead HK$0.02 to HK$5.40 after 1.37 million shares changed hands, brokers said.
Diesel engine maker Changchai was the third most actively traded issue and put on HK$0.05 to HK$5.06 on volume of 660,800 shares.

The A share market fell on a technical correction, brokers said. The A share index dipped 5.90 points, or 1.92 percent, to close at 301.43 on massive turnover of 10.47 billion yuan, compared with Tuesday's 9.85 billion yuan.
The composite index edged down 5.31 points, or 1.84 percent, to finish at 283.25.

Shenyang Fangtian was the target of profit-taking after the Shenzhen-based Securities Times quoted a company spokesman as denying rumours that Fangtian would reap substantial profits from the sale of a property project this year.
The counter slid 0.80 yuan, or 8.60 percent, to 8.50 yuan on heavy trade of 16.87 million shares.
